Problem:
Consider a continuous function z defined as the convolution of two functions x and h on a real line, denoted as z(t) = (x * h)(t). This convolution operation represents the integral of the product of x shifted by -s and h, as function of s from negative to positive infinity. The analysis focuses on how differentiating z with respect to t, as well as considering the Fourier transform of x and h, impacts the resulting function.

If at a certain moment \\( t = t_0 \\) an impulse function is applied as an intervention on function h, does this affect the convolution z at all times t?
Explanation: The introduction of an impulse function in h at \\( t_0 \\) acts essentially as a Dirac delta function, which leaves a clear signature on z by adding the scaled version of x at \\( t_0 \\); hence it changes z at all times t.
